title: Azir Q behaviour changes
body:
Hello friends of Shurima!

One of the long standing issues that we've had with Azir is that his Q behaved a little unpredictably sometimes. UnknownMartian most recently posted a Youtube video to reddit that lays out the problem clearly:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AgdmjXMs7tI

TLDR: When assigning soldiers positions for Conquering Sands (Q), Azir would historically grab all soldiers on the map in random order (most often this would happen to be in order of creation, but not always). As demonstrated in the video, in the three soldier case this sometimes leads to an unfortunate situation where the nearest soldier is assigned one of the side positions, 240 units off your mouse cursor.

I took some time tonight to rewrite how Q works and cleaned up some bugs surrounding the 2/4 soldier cases as well (4 soldiers is technically possible, but very, very rare). Here's the breakdown, with pictures!

http://i.imgur.com/XxWuN12.png
**One soldier**
Pretty straightforward. Goes where you click. Your click position is a 75 radius green circle, the calculated soldier position is a 100 radius red circle. In this case they're identical

http://i.imgur.com/FTF77t1.png
**Two soldiers**
The soldiers align themselves around your target position, equidistant to the left and right of it. The nearest soldier always goes to the left position, viewed from Azir's perspective along the axis of your cast direction.

http://i.imgur.com/S8XhAyT.png
**Three soldiers**
This is the situation from Unknown Martian's video. I fixed this so the nearest soldier will always go to the MIDDLE, which is the position that you clicked on. The second closest will go to the left and the farthest will go to the right.

http://i.imgur.com/vTkJXGD.png
**Four soldiers**
This is very rare and hard to achieve. Hint: both Q and AA extend soldier lifetime by a fractional amount in certain situations. Not something I expect players will be able to exploit in real games, but just in case. As you can see, the first row of soldiers places itself slightly nearer to you than where you clicked, with the nearest soldier going to the center. This is only a difference of 120 units, and Q overshoots by 50 units, so this difference shouldn't make you miss (we do check forward an additional 100 units at the end of a Q to see if we can find someone to hit anyway, so it's a moot point).

None of this has been QA checked yet so details may change or the rollout of these changes may be delayed. They will also not be in the next patch; at the earliest, they will be in the patch after that.

Questions?

Zenon, this will sound insulting but I just mean it objectively: why are your release champions so buggy? Is it cause you design complex champions? Is this just Riot releasing champions without performing unit and integration tests?

> [{quoted}](name=matrinox,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=kWNzO2EP,comment-id=000d,timestamp=2015-01-07T15:08:04.528+0000)
>
> Zenon, this will sound insulting but I just mean it objectively: why are your release champions so buggy? Is it cause you design complex champions? Is this just Riot releasing champions without performing unit and integration tests?

Yeah they're making them more complex and that brings out more bugs. But those are not unit/integration tests. Those are user experience tests. 

As someone who does code, those kind of kink look like "lazy" coding. The programmer/scripter made it to work as it was supposed to work in the simplest way for *him*. He didn't fully think about every way a player might use the skill. The skill seems to be used as either repositioning for AA or soldier-poke in lane. The former works as intended and the later works as long as you have 1 soldier or that the soldiers are coming from the same spot.

That kink wouldn't have been discovered untill people played azir long enough to chase an enemy with soldiers currently in the field, then drop a new one, then Q him (like the video showed). Then the first few times, the player will think it was his mistake. Then he'll start to realize it happens a lot and will try to understand why. Chances are the playtesters never got far enough to notice there was some weird behavior.
 They were probably in the "oh I made a mistake" part. Or they made their setup knowing that the new soldier would need an AA. Maybe BECAUSE they knew how his Q worked.

Yeah I agree with you. I'm a programmer as well and a great example of this issue I'm bringing up is when they discovered the problem with damage amp on a certain champ (was it talon first?). Hey should have written unit tests to test that x damage is y% less when activating ability z. Instead, many months later Sona was discovered not having her damage reduction in her empowered W working. It's like they're not even testing happy paths (using unit tests).

I also don't think it should be integration tests since you should be able to measure damages via server code since it's all hosted there.

Well, honestly, there are millions of players and only what? a few hundred (if that) rioters? in the 2 hrs after a champ is released, that champ will have been "play tested" by the players for more hours than riot could possibly perform if they play tested that champ for an entire year. 

So even if riot does their utmost best to test a champ for all possible bugs, they will never be able to put in the man hours that the player base will do after the champ is released, so even if everything checks out at riot hq, the players will still find things riot never noticed simply due to the nature of the players being able to play test EVERY single possibility and freak accident possible in less than a week.

This is a nice fix. I love Azir's design on paper, but his abilities are so mechanically frustrating an unpredictable that I broke down and refunded him after 3 rage inducing games in a row.

One annoying aspect that ought to be addressed is attacking people right on the edge of a soldier's range (which is often where they end up when you Q a fleeing opponent) Sometimes the attack goes through, other times Azir runs his dumb squishy ass into the middle of the enemy team to AA the target himself, which gets him blown up. The difference is 1 unit.

If it were at all possible, I'd like a means of controlling my character that lets me completely separate camera movement, character movement, and attacking. That would make Azir a lot more playable.
